docs.lead_paragraph: Humana Inc. said yesterday that first-quarter earnings fell 26 percent, as a decline in the number of members in its health plans offset higher revenue from Medicare. Humana, an operator of health maintenance organizations, earned $39 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $53 million, or 32 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $1.83 billion.
docs.abstract: Humana Inc says first-quarter earnings fell 26 percent; company earned $39 million compared with $53 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 15 percent, to $1.83 billion; table (S)
docs.snippet: Humana Inc. said yesterday that first-quarter earnings fell 26 percent, as a decline in the number of members in its health plans offset higher revenue from Medicare.    Humana, an operator of health maintenance organizations, earned $39 million, or...

docs.lead_paragraph: The stock market rocketed yesterday to its greatest gain in more than five years because a key economic indicator, measuring labor costs, showed no sign of inflation despite a robust economy and many reports that skilled workers are increasingly hard to find. Nothing in the Employment Cost Index, the broadest measure of what employers pay for workers, suggested that rising labor costs might soon force companies to raise their prices. Wages did rise modestly, but not across the board. And outlays for benefits like health insurance and pensions were almost unchanged.

headline.main: Markets Surge As Labor Costs Stay in Check

docs.abstract: Stock market rockets to its greatest gain in over five years--2.64 percent for the Dow Jones industrial average--when Employment Cost Index, key economic indicator measuring labor costs, shows no sign of inflation despite robust economy and many reports that skilled workers are increasingly hard to find; mild inflation report, showing rise in employment costs of just six-tenths of 1 percent for first quarter, takes some of steam out of view on Wall Street that Federal Reserve will soon feel compelled to raise interest rates again to slow economy; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The stock market rocketed yesterday to its greatest gain in more than five years because a key economic indicator, measuring labor costs, showed no sign of inflation despite a robust economy and many reports that skilled workers are increasingly hard...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans today rejected proposals that would have given individual senators a greater role in deciding who gets to sit on Federal appeals courts. The Republican conference voted after a heated debate on proposals that would have given conservatives more influence in opposing President Clinton's nominees for the Federal bench.

headline.main: Move to Limit Clinton's Judicial Choices Fails

docs.abstract: US Senate Republicans reject proposals that would have given individual senators a greater role in deciding who gets to sit on Federal appeals courts; Republican conference votes on proposals that would have given conservatives more influence on opposing Pres Clinton's nominees for Federal bench; Senate Republicans approve largely symbolic resolution that condemns 'activist judges' on Federal bench and calls for Republicans to scrutinize judicial nominees closely to prevent anyone from being confirmed who might become that kind of judge (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Diversity is on all lips. So is closure. So is icon. Just try to get through the day without reading or hearing about someone who is an icon, someone who is looking for closure and someone who is championing diversity. Oh yes, it can be done if you cut the plugs off your radios and television sets and burn all newspapers and magazines as they come through the door. Only the strongest can do that. The child for whose benefit I cut the plug off the TV set in 1949 has not spoken to me since.
docs.abstract: Russell Baker Op-Ed column on some foolish expressions, or blather, that has come to typify speech of many Americans; focuses on common use of words closure, diversity and icon (M)ï
